title: S grade on a loss is literal 1v9
body:
Please do correct me if i'm making an over simplification or im being ignorant to what the grades mean.

But doesnt an S grade necessarily imply that you couldnt have played any better? by the standards of everyone who plays league of legends you played as well as you could have possibly played in that game.

Now doesnt playing as well as you could have possibly played, imply that you were beating the enemy team well enough to secure an S grade? surely if you were losing even by a the slightest margin, an S grade would be impossible given that to play the best you could possibly play, you couldnt be losing, lest youd be impeded and unable to play a 100% game and therefore unable to secure an s grade.

So how is it possible to lose a game and secure an S grade? surely if your team were doing badly, then as has already been previously stated - if there is a player on the team who is securing an s grade - then that team are winning.

i propose the only way it could be possible to lose and get an s grade is if that your team were so bad, that their net contribution to the game was helping the other team which implies that they would be more use to the person securing the s grade by being afk. this is the literal 1v9 (it is in my experience that the 1v9 is typical of these types of loses, where usually if there was at least one other player on the team making a meaningful contribution, defeat would be avoided) , where team mates are so bad that they they are helping the other team and would be better being afk. in this scenario, a player who is outplaying the opposition team sufficiently to secure an s grade can lose when the opposition team are handed a route to victory, even though they are losing, by the team mates of the person who is outplaying them.

its worth pointing out in this scenario, the player is significantly better than the opposition team, but his team are significantly worse than the opposition. it begs the question why would such a miss match of skill ever occur

and this brings us to the crux of the argument, if a player is given a team that are so bad, that it makes it impossible to win, then how can rito pretend that matches are anywhere near balanced - that their match making system actually works?

how can they say. "well you know, the reason why you lose your games is because you didnt play well enough, learn from your mistakes and youl start climbing", when they are literally handed impossible matches, where ritos own system is telling them that they played as well as anyone could have possibly played.

its worth mentioning something about the frequency of these games. if they were a rarity, maybe once a season, this could be ignored as an anomaly in the match making and / or rating system. but it happens all too frequently, as i am typing, of the 4 games i played tonight, i lost 3, won 1 and scored s grades in 3 of them - 2 out of 4 of my games were s grade loses. last season i even had an s grade annie defeat where i did over 100k damage, i was getting on for double the damage of the next person inb4: damage isnt everything. i know, but it counts for something

feel free to pick apart my reasoning, please share experiences.

I can get an S on a losing team if I play GP and afk farm all day, and just kill anyone who comes to my lane. I can ignore my team and contribute nothing to team fights but splitpush and farm literally the entire time, with a nice lookin' KDA and CS, and that's all I'll need to get that S. It DOES NOT mean that you've played to the absolute best of your ability, it just means that you've played well according to algorithms that measure the standard, measurable things.

There are things that can't be measured with the algorithm, like shot-calling. Getting your team to organize can win the game. I've had players go C+ in some of my games but they were the only reason I'd ever say we won, because they kept us focused on things that actually mattered and got us to win the game.

that a person can be doing what could be termed as "afk farming" and still be rewarded with an S grade, ie make no meaningful contribution to the team effort to secure objectives and by the algorithms that issue the grades, still be told that they played well, i would suggest is evidence that the current grading system is broken / not fit for purpose

i guess one line of reasoning would be that "there are limitations to how well a programmed system can judge a players skill"

to this i would say that i would think / hope that there is room for improvement. not being privy to the specifics of the system it would be hard for me to comment on such things, but just from anecdotal observation it appears to be unusually weighted to CS score, and less towards things such as securing neutral objectives.

but if we are going to accept that the system is perhaps as robust as it could be, then it should be asked why has rito got a system implemented that rewards people for not working with their team to win?

You can play better than an S+, S+ just means you are in the top X percent of X players in X ELO and X lane. You cant really go higher in grade, but S is a range.

Someone getting an S+ in bronze is nowhere near good at their champion compared to someone getting an S+ in the same conditions in gold or plat.

> i dont even see how the logic in this argument follows

Because you dont understand the science of statistics and are not considering anything that does not directly relate to you.

An S rank does not mean you played the best possible game, it means you played better than a certain percentage of other players. There is no upper limit, because that is statistically impossible.

The bonus is in place to prevent people from trying to farm a high score without making any effort to win.

You can still get an S on a loss if you score high enough that you pass the grade curve for an S without the bonus, it just takes more work than getting an S in a win.

Riot is not giving _you_ unwinnable games, they are evenly dividing players (or trying to) based on ELO. Consider all the times the _other team_ has the 0/12 Garen. Basically 50/50, nothing else is statistically possible over enough time. Both teams have an equal chance of getting the idiot.

Unless it is you dragging your team down (or carrying), your winrate over a big enough sample size will always be 50%.

Small sample size (under several hundred games) are meaningless, as random luck skews the results more. Consider a sample size of 2 games: it is just as likely to be 0/2, 1/1 or 2/0. A sample size of 100 is much more averaged out.

LP gain/loss has to start depending somehow on your own performance. It's just too ridiculous when it doesn't. It should be a running joke that they actually use an Elo system for a team game.

This can happen when the losing S rank picks an early comp and destroys the enemy winning team all game but does not know how to focus objective and to push to win. Then the losing S grade lets the game go on for too long and the other team has a comp that will out scale them and 1 bad team fight 45 minutes in and BAM losing S grade.  
I have had a good handful of games were I get S as support or top and lose.  A few as adc. But this is a team game that require everyone to play together for the most part and if you are winning you need to push your advantages. Look at TSM, they lose early every game because they know they can out micro manage late game or they pick scaling comps. Doesn't always work.... but they try it a lot.
I do agree and have said it many times that match making is a troll fest of luck, and its -50% when you enter promos, but Riot stands by their BLIND belief that its as fair as can be.

recalling now, that S grade 100k+ dmg annie win was a big mid game advantage

but cant failure to convert an advantage into a win be evidence for 1v9?

doesnt an uneven game such as a 4v5 bcome harder and harder to win the longer the game goes on?

if a person was hyper carrying and that carrying conferred an advantage wouldnt it be nigh impossible to convert that advantage to a win if their team mates net effort was helping the other team?

unless that person manage to destroy the enemy nexus or get the enemy team to surrender in the mid / early game, any advantage they had would be quickly mitigated once the enemy team finally got to their full builds. pressing an advantage in a 1v9 could be possible whilst snowballing but 1v5ing a full build team who have the help of 4 feeders would be nigh impossible.

in that particular game, it wasnt lost by one fight, the enemy manage to win a few fights and turn the tide, i was certainly losing when i lost and secured that s grade.

which is consistent with what i described in OP and my last reply to you, getting an S grade whilst losing / having lost

not to say that its not impossible for a team to lose a game they are winning after losing one fight, ive seen it in pro games - which have probably been some of the most memorable games - and i have seen it in games i have played. but i cant vouch for the frequency of achieving an S grade in such defeats as i cant recount any but again i would suggest that its perhaps because they are an outlier (if they happen at all).

i would suggest a perfectly intuitive argument to the kind of scenario you have described is that if you cant convert an advantage into a win, then you arent playing as well as you could be and so shouldnt be rewarded with an S grade.

anecdotally i have felt that this is the case. its worth noting that the following scenario usually happens in wins, but i believe its relevant.

I would have a phenomenal early / mid game but then have trouble pressing the advantage and converting that into a more immediate victory. the game transitions into late game and my late game is less impressive that the mid / early - for what ever reason, bad scaling, loss of concentration, what ever. the other players on my team start to have more of a bearing on the game and manage to secure a late game victory. and boom, what i was sure would have been an s grade around the mid game, earns me an A grade.

and this is completely fair and intuative

but what i guess you are describing is more of a throwing of a won game. this immediate defeat against the run of play again can be intuitively seen to reward an S from a loss. one fight changing a 100% game into a 99.9% game.

i would suggest though that such an s grade loss would be an outlier, i would be interested to hear your thoughts on their frequency. but, these games are not typical of the types of S grade loss i experience.

im talking about games where there never was a team advantage. im talking about games where we maybe dont even secure one tower or drake. im talking about games where i might be laying complete waste and devastation to the enemy team where ever i am in the map, maybe even securing first tower and the next in my lane, but my top lane for example decides they are just going to abandon their lane and let the enemy top free farm and get them a clear route into our base.

as i have said before im talking about games where my team are so bad that its like playing against 9 players. where even if im literally dominating the enemy team of 5 well enough to get an s grade. they have 4 additional players that the algorithms dont account for helping them.

maybe thats the true nature of the S grade loss

when the systems think u achieved an S grade against 5 people, but it never accounted for the fact that you were actually playing 9 people, and if that was factored in your performance against them was maybe an A grade or less.

TLDR; rito, either admit that you are giving us games that are impossible to win, or stop telling us after a defeat that we couldnt have played any better when you tell us that losing is because we are bad.
